title: Satisfaction with healthcare quality in Finland
text:
(You can interact with this map and hover your cursor over region to see the % of positive client experience)
© Made by Larkina Yelyzaveta
In 2024 year, North Karelia had the lowest healthcare satisfaction at 49.5%, while Ostrobothnia had the highest at 63.8%. Depending on the Finnish region, every 2nd or 3rd patient was not satisfied with Finnish healthcare.

title: Satisfaction with healthcare quality in Finland
text:
(You can interact with this map and hover your cursor over region to see the % of positive client experience)

In 2024 year, North Karelia had the lowest healthcare satisfaction at 49.5%, while Ostrobothnia had the highest at 63.8%. Depending on the Finnish region, every 2nd or 3rd patient was not satisfied with Finnish healthcare.

title: Satisfaction with healthcare quality in Finland
text:
Patient satisfication exploration

© Made by Gnaneswar Vinta
Trust to Finnish healthcare has been decreasing from 83% to 54% during 2020-2024 years.

title: Satisfaction with healthcare quality in Finland
text:
Continuity of care in Finland

© Made by Larkina Yelyzaveta
In 2024, 15–30% of Finnish patients visited the same assigned doctor or nurse. The factor of having different doctor and nurse every visit may be one of the reasons why patients are unhappy with healthcare.

title: Satisfaction with healthcare quality in Finland
section: Healthcare trends: health status vs. healthcare expenditure
text:
Healthcare trends: health status vs. healthcare expenditure

© Made by Gnaneswar Vinta
During the few last years, the exponditure on healthcare has been raising among Finnish patients. Due to the fact, it most likely be one of the reasons why people are not satified with healthcare system in Finland.

title: Satisfaction with healthcare quality in Finland
section: Healthcare system efficiency matrix: Finland vs. European countries
text:
Healthcare system efficiency matrix: Finland vs. European countries

© Made by Gnaneswar Vinta
Finland has great results in integration healthcare system among some other European countries. On the contrary to this, it also shows that Finland has the worst results in patient satisfaction.

title: Satisfaction with healthcare quality in Finland
text:
Healthcare transformation prediction

© Made by Gnaneswar Vinta
Because of the recent upcoming changes, we’re predicting that Finland is awaiting positive outcomes from current laws around 2030 year and will become a leader among Nordic countries in health status.

title: Satisfaction with healthcare quality in Finland
text:
Finnish healthcare transformation by 2030 year

© Made by Gnaneswar Vinta
Our final say is that Finland will be raising in the global rank in healthcare field and patient’s satisfaction will be increased slightly. And population health focus will change: transition from treatment-centered to prevention-centered system​.

title: Why we have started this mini-project
text:
In recent years, Yle, the Finnish news source, has published several articles highlighting issues in Finland’s healthcare system. For example:



Yle logo


Logo © Yle — used here for educational purposes only.

Central Finland wellbeing services county has announced job cuts affecting some 330 people, after talks with unions that began in August.

Read more at this Yle article

In 2021, 96 percent of Finns said they trusted the healthcare system. By June 2024, the level of trust had dropped to 83 percent. The report (in Finnish) drew on results from the government-commissioned Citizens’ Pulse survey between 2021 and 2024.

Read more by this link

Recently, the government announced plans to increase the >maximum customer fees for social and healthcare services >in its draft budget proposal, enabling welfare regions >to charge patients more.


Depending on the region, visits to a health centre next year may see an increase of five euros, raising the fee to about 28 euros. The hospital outpatient fee will increase by approximately 20 euros, bringing it to nearly 70 euros.

Read more here




The Yle logo is the property of Yle – Finnish Broadcasting Company and is used here for educational purposes only.
Articles and content cited from Yle remain the intellectual property of their respective authors.
The author of this website does not claim ownership of these materials.





The challenges in Finland’s healthcare system can be summarized as follows:



Increasing healthcare fees

Job cuts in the healthcare sector

Lower patient trust

Growing mental health concerns






Long waiting times

Difficulty accessing service information

Rushed primary care appointments

Communication gaps between providers

Regional inequality in service access






Staff professionalism and friendliness

Effective treatments

Universal access regardless of income

Convenient digital services

High-quality emergency care


All of these reasons and their highlight in Finnish news made us to investigate the data about how satisfied patients in healthcare are and comparing it to other countries healthcare.

title: Satisfaction with healthcare quality in Finland
text:
This page summarizes the key contributions and sources.




© 2025 by Larkina Yelyzaveta.
All rights for creating this website belong solely to Larkina Yelyzaveta. Before sharing anything publicly from this website, please do ask permission.





THL – Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare – Open statistics on healthcare access and satisfaction.

Yle News – Articles and reports discussing the healthcare situation in Finland.

Official Statistics of Finland (OSF) – Regional data on population and healthcare resources.






The Yle logo is the property of Yle – Finnish Broadcasting Company and is used here for educational and non-commercial purposes.

Other icons and illustrations are sourced from Flaticon and Unsplash under free-use licenses.

Custom plots and animations are made by Larkina Yelyzaveta and additional statistic graphs made by Gnaneswar Vinta.





This website was created as a small data science exploration to understand public satisfaction with healthcare quality in Finland.
It has no commercial intent — purely educational and research-focused.

 This project is not affiliated with any commercial institution.
All opinions and interpretations belong solely to the author.
